messageBody:
This IS a good point, and one I'd like to support.
*IF* you think it can break, or it *HAS* broken in the
past and caused you to waste time tracking it down,
test it.

Using macros and coding conventions is fine, and if
you think that is enough, good for you. Go with that.

If you'd rather test the setters and getters (maybe
even of just one or two classes), also well and good.

Personally, I tend not to test simple getters and
setters. I may, however, after an incident a few
weeks ago (which caused my partner and I to waste a
good 45 minutes), test any constructors that set
member variables, even if they look simple.

I think the point lots of people don't quite get is
that this is fairly subjective. There is not really,
as far as I know, a 'YOU MUST TEST THIS OR ELSE'
directive anywhere, either in JUnit or XP. Test what
you feel comfortable testing that gives you confidence
in your system.

It also seems that, for some people, ignorance
replaces confidence ... ;)

-Eric

--- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@...>
wrote:
> > Sirs,
>
> > I think this is important point and it is also
> possible to be added
> > to FAQ:
> >
> > many programmers writes setters in following style
> (let's call it
> > IBM-style)
>
> That's actually VAJ-style. :)
>
> > void setValue(ValueType newValue)
> > {
> > value=newValue;
> > }
> >
> > while others preffer to do it in Sun-style:
> >
> > void setValue(ValueType value)
> > {
> > this.value=value;
> > }
> >
> > now just imagine that while edditing your code you
> just pressed
> > "del" key in "void setValue(ValueType value)" or
> made other typing
> > mistake and got "void setValue(ValueType vale)" in
> this case code
> > will compile BUT "this.value=value;" will be
> equivalent
> to "this.value=this.value;"
> > some times such errors are very hard to find it
> out... If you have special
> > test case for set/get you will find problem within
> seconds if not
> > you will find problem only because other tests are
> failed...
>
> I agree that typos can make even the simplest code
> break, but if you want
> your tests to catch every typo, then you'll be
> testing forever. (If you want
> to test forever, I won't stop you, unless you're
> delivering code I'm
> responsible for.) There are higher-level approaches
> to this problem:
>
> * Use macros to generate the source for
> getX()/setX() methods.
>
> * Stop writing JavaBeans; start writing objects. (I
> wish more people would do
> this. JavaBeans are *not* objects, they are just
> bags of data. If you're not
> using them with a JavaBeans tool, then write real
> objects!)
>
> * Use a coding convention that eliminates the
> problem. Some people like
> underscores in their fields (I don't, particularly),
> some people like "a" at
> the beginning of a formal parameter name (means
> "argument"), some people like
> to always do an explicit "this." Pick one and go
> with it. If a coding
> convention can avoid the problem, great.
>
> Remember: test until fear turns to boredom. If
> you're afraid of coding a
> method incorrectly, then test it; that includes
> getX()/setX(). All we're
> saying is that many people don't fear methods this
> simple, so we don't test
> them, and we provide our justifications in terms of
> diminishing returns.
>
> If you spend three hours hunting down a bug because
> some careless person
> wrote "value = value", that's a shame; however,
> writing 10000 tests, one for
> every getX()/setX() method, may not be the most
> effective use of your time.
> As always, YMMV.
>
> > Sorry, for beating the air...
>
> No, this is a good part of the argument that should
> probably be pointed out.
> Thank you for bringing it up.
>
